Yaad (ours) 2222-layer MLP Huber L2 GD Wt=αt⁢Wt−1−{ηt⁢∇ℓ2⁢(Wt−1;𝐤t,𝐯t)if‖ℳ⁢(𝐤t)−𝐯t‖≤δt,ηt⁢δt⁢∇ℓ1⁢(Wt−1;𝐤t,𝐯t)Otherwise.subscript𝑊𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡1casessubscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ2subscript𝑊𝑡1subscript𝐤𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡ifnormℳsubscript𝐤𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡subscript𝛿𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝛿𝑡∇subscriptℓ1subscript𝑊𝑡1subscript𝐤𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡OtherwiseW_{t}=\alpha_{t}W_{t-1}-\begin{cases}\eta_{t}\>\nabla\ell_{2}(W_{t-1};\mathbf{% k}_{t},\mathbf{v}_{t})&\text{if}\quad\|\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{k}_{t})-\mathbf{v}_% {t}\|\leq\delta_{t},\\ \eta_{t}\>\delta_{t}\nabla\ell_{1}(W_{t-1};\mathbf{k}_{t},\mathbf{v}_{t})&% \text{Otherwise}.\end{cases}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - { start_ROW start_CELL italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL if ∥ caligraphic_M ( bold_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL Otherwise . end_CELL end_ROW
Memora (ours) 2222-layer MLP L2 KL GD Wt=Softmax⁢(αt⁢log⁡(Wt−1)−ηt⁢∇ℓ2⁢(Wt−1;𝐤t,𝐯t))subscript𝑊𝑡Softmaxsubscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝑊𝑡1subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscriptℓ2subscript𝑊𝑡1subscript𝐤𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡W_{t}=\mbox{Softmax}\left(\alpha_{t}\log(W_{t-1})-\eta_{t}\nabla\ell_{2}(W_{t-% 1};\mathbf{k}_{t},\mathbf{v}_{t})\right)italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Softmax ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
∗ is using multiple rounds of GD per token.
† For the sake of clarity, we use L2 for all modified L2-like regularizations. However, in fact, only Titans and RWKV-7 are using L2 retention gate (see Section 4)
caption: Table 1: Overview of recent sequence models in Miras framework perspective. Surprisingly, all models are using the same type of attentional bias and regularization (forget gate). Note that these architectural choices does not uniquely identify the backbone as there are other design choices (e.g., input-dependency, channel-wise parameters, etc.) as well as the use of other components such as attention, convolutions, etc. Note that for attentional bias and retention gate, we are referring to the original design of Miras, discussed in Equation 4 and Remark 1.
description: This table categorizes various sequence models based on the MIRAS framework's four key architectural choices: memory architecture, attentional bias, retention gate, and memory learning algorithm.  It reveals a surprising uniformity, showing that most models use the same attentional bias and regularization despite differing in other architectural aspects (input dependency, channel-wise parameters, use of attention or convolutions, etc.). The table provides a comparative overview of these models, illustrating their components within the MIRAS framework's conceptual structure and highlighting design choices that could be further explored for improved sequence modeling.
section: 3 Associative Memory, Attentional Bias, and Retention

caption:
Table 2: 
Performance of Miras’s variants and baselines on language modeling and common-sense reasoning tasks. Hybrid models are marked with ∗. The best results of simple and hybrid models are highlighted. In largest scale, we compare our simple models with even hybrid models and highlight the best results.
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of various sequence models, including the authors' proposed MIRAS variants (MONETA, YAAD, MEMORA), against several established baselines (Transformer++, RetNet, GLA, Mamba, DeltaNet, TTT, and Gated DeltaNet) on language modeling and common-sense reasoning tasks.  The results are categorized by model size (340M, 760M, and 1.3B parameters) and include key metrics such as perplexity (ppl), accuracy (acc), and accuracy (acc_n) for different datasets. Hybrid models, incorporating both recurrent and attention mechanisms, are marked with an asterisk (*). The best performing models, both simple and hybrid, for each task and size are highlighted, offering a comprehensive comparison of different architectural approaches across various scales.

caption: Table 3: Performance of Moneta, Yaad, Memora, and baselines on NIAH task from RULER benchmark. The best results with highest accuracy are highlighted.
description: This table presents the performance comparison of three novel sequence models (MONETA, YAAD, and MEMORA) introduced in the paper and several baseline models on the Needle In Haystack (NIAH) task from the RULER benchmark.  The NIAH task evaluates a model's ability to retrieve specific information (the "needle") from a larger context containing distracting information (the "haystack"). The table shows the accuracy of each model on three variations of the NIAH task (S-NIAH-PK, S-NIAH-N, S-NIAH-W) with different sequence lengths (1K, 2K, 4K, and 8K tokens). The best-performing model for each setting is highlighted.

caption: Table 4: Ablation study on the components of Yaad.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the YAAD model, analyzing the impact of various design choices on its performance.  It shows the average language modeling perplexity scores when different components are removed or replaced.  The components tested include the retention gate, input dependency, l2 loss, l1 loss, and the MLP architecture (replacing it with a linear layer). This analysis helps to understand the contribution of each component to the overall performance of the YAAD model.

170M 12 768 16 3e-3 15B

caption: Table 5: Architectural Details.
description: Table 5 presents the architectural specifications for the various models used in the experiments.  It details the number of layers (Block), the dimensionality of the embedding (Dim), the number of attention heads (Head), the peak learning rate (Peak LR) used during training, and the total number of tokens used in training (Token) for each model size (170M, 340M, 780M parameters). This table provides essential context for understanding the experimental setup and comparing the performance results of different models with varying architectural characteristics.
